elements.content: An in situ approach has been undertaken to synthesize a series of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with the pore surface functionalized via the organic linkers of multi N-heterocycles. This was done so as to explore their stability, flexibility, and adsorption behaviors on the basis of the nature of metal centers (M = Zn, Mg, Co, Ni). Four isoreticular MOFs based on in situ synthesized T-shaped ligands were obtained, and their phase purity and stability were investigated in conjunction with the adsorption properties for a wide range of gases (Ar, N2, H2, CO2, CH4, C2H6, C2H4, C3H8, and C3H6). The results revealed that the stability of MOF based on Ni2+ is better than those of Mg, Zn, and Co analogues, and that the multi N-heterocycles ligand endows these MOFs with higher affinity for CO2, C2H6, C2H4, C3H8, and C3H6, leading to an excellent selectivity for these gases over CH4.
elements.clean_text: An in situ approach has been undertaken to synthesize a series of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with the pore surface functionalized via the organic linkers of multi N-heterocycles. This was done so as to explore their stability, flexibility, and adsorption behaviors on the basis of the nature of metal centers (M = Zn, Mg, Co, Ni). Four isoreticular MOFs based on in situ synthesized T-shaped ligands were obtained, and their phase purity and stability were investigated in conjunction with the adsorption properties for a wide range of gases (Ar, N2, H2, CO2, CH4, C2H6, C2H4, C3H8, and C3H6). The results revealed that the stability of MOF based on Ni2+ is better than those of Mg, Zn, and Co analogues, and that the multi N-heterocycles ligand endows these MOFs with higher affinity for CO2, C2H6, C2H4, C3H8, and C3H6, leading to an excellent selectivity for these gases over CH4.

elements.content: Four isoreticular metal−organic frameworks were obtained by rationally utilizing in situ solvothermal reactions. Systematical examination of their structural features and gas adsorption/separation behaviors highlights the significant effect of metal centers on each framework.
elements.clean_text: Four isoreticular metal-organic frameworks were obtained by rationally utilizing in situ solvothermal reactions. Systematical examination of their structural features and gas adsorption/separation behaviors highlights the significant effect of metal centers on each framework.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Within the last few decades, the discovery and development of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been one of the most inspiring events in the chemical world. Plenty of research results have witnessed the diverse structures and striking application of MOFs on guest sorption and separation, luminescence properties, catalysis, sensors, and so on. One of the most intriguing properties of some MOFs is their structural flexibility, which is hardly observed in other porous materials like zeolites and activated carbons. The phenomenon involves a diverse range of conformational factors that result in the reversible adjustment of pore size and shape to external stimuli such as physisorption, temperature, mechanical force, and light. We mainly focus on the guest-induced flexibility, which grants enhanced application for flexible MOFs in gas separation. For some guests that can induce structural transformation from a closed aperture to open aperture caused by specific host–guest interactions, it is usually accompanied by an abrupt rise of adsorption amount of the guests and resulting stepwise behavior in measured isotherms. On the contrary, nontarget guests cannot induce the aforementioned structural transformation for the reason for having a lack of weak affinity to the guest, thus causing a wide gap between the adsorption amount of the specific guests and nontarget guests and leading to splendid guest selectivity properties. Such behavior is one of the most effective ways to enrich desired gas molecules, creating a bright prospect in industrial applications. Although fruitful results have been obtained in relation to the structural details during the flexible transformation, it is still unclear why some MOFs possess flexibility. In other words, the inherent factors that cause flexibility of some specific framework are still an important goal in the field of researching MOFs. In situ ligand reactions are another field that has been extensively investigated because they can provide a one-step synthetic method for organic compounds that require multiple reactions under conventional conditions or are even inaccessible in direct preparation. The in situ reactions include reduction, oxidation, and displacement to form a new ligand with modified functional groups. The generated ligand is then formed in crystalline coordination products. By consciously utilizing the in situ ligand reactions strategy, some MOFs with novel network topologies and specific function can be constructed. However, owing to sensitive reaction conditions and unclear mechanism, in situ ligand reactions are still rare and difficult to extend to other synthetic conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Within the last few decades, the discovery and development of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been one of the most inspiring events in the chemical world. Plenty of research results have witnessed the diverse structures and striking application of MOFs on guest sorption and separation, luminescence properties, catalysis, sensors, and so on. One of the most intriguing properties of some MOFs is their structural flexibility, which is hardly observed in other porous materials like zeolites and activated carbons. The phenomenon involves a diverse range of conformational factors that result in the reversible adjustment of pore size and shape to external stimuli such as physisorption, temperature, mechanical force, and light. We mainly focus on the guest-induced flexibility, which grants enhanced application for flexible MOFs in gas separation. For some guests that can induce structural transformation from a closed aperture to open aperture caused by specific host-guest interactions, it is usually accompanied by an abrupt rise of adsorption amount of the guests and resulting stepwise behavior in measured isotherms. On the contrary, nontarget guests cannot induce the aforementioned structural transformation for the reason for having a lack of weak affinity to the guest, thus causing a wide gap between the adsorption amount of the specific guests and nontarget guests and leading to splendid guest selectivity properties. Such behavior is one of the most effective ways to enrich desired gas molecules, creating a bright prospect in industrial applications. Although fruitful results have been obtained in relation to the structural details during the flexible transformation, it is still unclear why some MOFs possess flexibility. In other words, the inherent factors that cause flexibility of some specific framework are still an important goal in the field of researching MOFs. In situ ligand reactions are another field that has been extensively investigated because they can provide a one-step synthetic method for organic compounds that require multiple reactions under conventional conditions or are even inaccessible in direct preparation. The in situ reactions include reduction, oxidation, and displacement to form a new ligand with modified functional groups. The generated ligand is then formed in crystalline coordination products. By consciously utilizing the in situ ligand reactions strategy, some MOFs with novel network topologies and specific function can be constructed. However, owing to sensitive reaction conditions and unclear mechanism, in situ ligand reactions are still rare and difficult to extend to other synthetic conditions.

elements.content: In this paper, four isostructural MOFs that were named as LIFM-13­(M) (M = Mg, Co, Ni, Zn, LIFM means Lehn Institute of Functional Materials), were formulated as M­(dimto)·solvent series, and were synthesized based on an unexpected in situ synthesized ligand of 4,6-di­(1-imidazolyl)-1,3,5-triazine-2-one (dimto) under heating in dimethylacetamide (DMAC) (). Single-crystal analyses have unambiguously verified their isostructures with quadrate pore shape and multi-nitrogen heterocyclic pore surface. Variant-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD) reveals that the frameworks exhibit different structural features varying from rigid to flexible by changing the metal centers, highlighting that metal centers play a crucial role in structural flexibility (or rigidity). Moreover, high gas adsorption selectivities benefit from the multi N-heterocycles ligand of the MOFs.
elements.clean_text: In this paper, four isostructural MOFs that were named as LIFM-13(M) (M = Mg, Co, Ni, Zn, LIFM means Lehn Institute of Functional Materials), were formulated as M(dimto)⋅solvent series, and were synthesized based on an unexpected in situ synthesized ligand of 4,6-di(1-imidazolyl)-1,3,5-triazine-2-one (dimto) under heating in dimethylacetamide (DMAC) (). Single-crystal analyses have unambiguously verified their isostructures with quadrate pore shape and multi-nitrogen heterocyclic pore surface. Variant-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD) reveals that the frameworks exhibit different structural features varying from rigid to flexible by changing the metal centers, highlighting that metal centers play a crucial role in structural flexibility (or rigidity). Moreover, high gas adsorption selectivities benefit from the multi N-heterocycles ligand of the MOFs.

elements.content:
In Situ Reaction from TIT to dimto, and the Formation of dimto Based LIFM-13­(M) with Various Flexible (or Rigid) Behavior<xref ref-type="fn" rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

M = Mg, Co, Ni, Zn.
elements.clean_text: 1  In Situ Reaction from TIT to dimto, and the Formation of dimto Based LIFM-13(M) with Various Flexible (or Rigid) Behavior      a M = Mg, Co, Ni, Zn.

elements.content:
M = Mg, Co, Ni, Zn.

Three MOFs of LIFM-13 have been structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses excluding LIFM-13­(Ni) (crystallographic data is shown in Tables S1 and S2 in Supporting Information). LIFM-13­(Zn), LIFM-13­(Mg), and LIFM-13­(Co) crystallize in space group I41/amd, I41/a, and I41, respectively. Single crystal structure analysis reveals that all the frameworks exhibit a similar structure. Herein we take LIFM-13­(Zn) as the example of all the analogues to show their structural details (). Similarly as compound of [Zn­(dimto)2] n ­·χ­(DMF), in LIFM-13­(Zn), one of the imidazole groups in the tripod ligand of 2,4,6-tri­(1-imidazolyl)-1,3,5-triazine (TIT) was broken and was replaced by a carbonyl group to afford a new T-shaped ligand (dimto). The feature of the CO double bond rather than single bond is confirmed by bond length of around 1.25 Å in each crystallographic data, and the existence of dimto was also confirmed by IR spectra (Figures S1–S4). Thus, the C 3 symmetry in TIT disappears and transfers into C 2 symmetry (Figure S5). The asymmetric unit of LIFM-13­(Zn) contains one Zn2+ and two ligands (solvent molecules are omitted) (a). The Zn2+ performs a hexahedral six coordinated mode, with two axial sites coordinating to two carbonyl groups, and the other four equatorial sites coordinating to four imidazole groups. Each dimto links three Zn2+, and the two imidazole groups in one ligand have the opposite coordination direction of 180°, also forming 90° with the coordination direction of the carbonyl group (Figure S5). In view of the ligand-to-axial approach, Zn2+ ions connect the imidazole groups of dimto forming sql 2D layers, which are further pillared by the carbonyl groups to afford the three-dimensional (3D) porous frameworks with considerable void spaces of 62.3% (void spaces of LIFM-13­(Mg) and LIFM-13­(Co) are 62.4% and 62.7%, respectively), as calculated by PLATON (Figure S6a–c). In view of topology, the Zn2+ ions serve as 6-connected nodes and the T-shaped ligands serve as three-connected nodes, thus generating a (3,6)-connected framework of ant topology, calculated by Topos 4.0 (Figure S6d).
elements.clean_text:
a M = Mg, Co, Ni, Zn.  

Three MOFs of LIFM-13 have been structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses excluding LIFM-13(Ni) (crystallographic data is shown in Tables S1 and S2 in Supporting Information). LIFM-13(Zn), LIFM-13(Mg), and LIFM-13(Co) crystallize in space group I41/amd, I41/a, and I41, respectively. Single crystal structure analysis reveals that all the frameworks exhibit a similar structure. Herein we take LIFM-13(Zn) as the example of all the analogues to show their structural details (). Similarly as compound of [Zn(dimto)2] n ⋅χ(DMF), in LIFM-13(Zn), one of the imidazole groups in the tripod ligand of 2,4,6-tri(1-imidazolyl)-1,3,5-triazine (TIT) was broken and was replaced by a carbonyl group to afford a new T-shaped ligand (dimto). The feature of the CO double bond rather than single bond is confirmed by bond length of around 1.25 Å in each crystallographic data, and the existence of dimto was also confirmed by IR spectra (Figures S1-S4). Thus, the C 3 symmetry in TIT disappears and transfers into C 2 symmetry (Figure S5). The asymmetric unit of LIFM-13(Zn) contains one Zn2+ and two ligands (solvent molecules are omitted) (a). The Zn2+ performs a hexahedral six coordinated mode, with two axial sites coordinating to two carbonyl groups, and the other four equatorial sites coordinating to four imidazole groups. Each dimto links three Zn2+, and the two imidazole groups in one ligand have the opposite coordination direction of 180°, also forming 90° with the coordination direction of the carbonyl group (Figure S5). In view of the ligand-to-axial approach, Zn2+ ions connect the imidazole groups of dimto forming  sql  2D layers, which are further pillared by the carbonyl groups to afford the three-dimensional (3D) porous frameworks with considerable void spaces of 62.3% (void spaces of LIFM-13(Mg) and LIFM-13(Co) are 62.4% and 62.7%, respectively), as calculated by PLATON (Figure S6a-c). In view of topology, the Zn2+ ions serve as 6-connected nodes and the T-shaped ligands serve as three-connected nodes, thus generating a (3,6)-connected framework of ant topology, calculated by Topos 4.0 (Figure S6d).

elements.content: Representation of the crystal structure of LIFM-13. (a) asymmetric unit and (b) 1D apertures of LIFM-13­(Zn), N sites are amplified to show the functional pore surface of the pore.
elements.clean_text: 1  Representation of the crystal structure of LIFM-13. (a) asymmetric unit and (b) 1D apertures of LIFM-13(Zn), N sites are amplified to show the functional pore surface of the pore.

elements.content: The purity of the as-synthesized compounds was confirmed by PXRD studies ( and Figure S7). These similar patterns also indicated that those four MOFs have a very similar structure except LIFM-13­(Mg). The thermal stability of MOFs is evaluated by thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) (Figure S8). The framework stability is tested by VT-PXRD measurements under N2 atmosphere (Figures S9–S12). The chemical decomposition process is related to bond breaking, and the corresponding temperature can be estimated by TGA measurements, while the framework collapse is correlated with the crystallinity of the solids that can be characterized by VT-PXRD. As seen from Figure S8, TGA curves of the as-prepared crystals show considerable weight loss before 200 °C, demonstrating that all MOFs contain large amounts of solvents within their pores. After desolvation, the TGA measurements of the dried samples indicate that the chemical decomposition of Ni-, Co-, and Zn-based MOFs mainly occur in a similar temperature range of 300–350 °C, which is significantly lower than that of Mg-based MOFs (450–500 °C). In contrast, the analysis of the VT-PXRD patterns collected for the four MOFs leads to another trend regarding their framework collapse (Figures S9–S12). LIFM-13­(Mg), LIFM-13­(Co), and LIFM-13­(Zn) retains their crystallinity up to 120 °C. LIFM-10­(Ni) shows a much better stability of up to 400 °C. These results suggest that Mg-, Co-, and Zn-based MOFs lose their porosity after the solvents are removed. Nevertheless, LIFM-13­(Ni) can maintain its crystallinity at a slightly higher temperature. This confirms that the Ni-based MOFs are more thermally stable when compared with the Mg-, Co-, and Zn-based analogues. On the basis of the Pearson’s hard/soft acid/base (HSAB) principle, the in situ obtained ligand dimto offers both coordination sites of imidazole group as a soft Lewis base and oxygen group as a hard lewis base; thus we hypothesize that Ni2+, which is either too hard acid like Mg2+ or too soft acid like Co2+/Zn2+, acts as a borderline acid that fits well with the hybrid coordination environment, giving LIFM-13­(Ni) the highest stability among its analogues. After all, this whole set of observations unveils that the thermal stability of a MOF may be different with regard to the chemical decomposition and the framework collapse.

These similar patterns also indicated that those four MOFs have a very similar structure except LIFM-13(Mg). The thermal stability of MOFs is evaluated by thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) (Figure S8). The framework stability is tested by VT-PXRD measurements under N2 atmosphere (Figures S9-S12). The chemical decomposition process is related to bond breaking, and the corresponding temperature can be estimated by TGA measurements, while the framework collapse is correlated with the crystallinity of the solids that can be characterized by VT-PXRD. As seen from Figure S8, TGA curves of the as-prepared crystals show considerable weight loss before 200 °C, demonstrating that all MOFs contain large amounts of solvents within their pores. After desolvation, the TGA measurements of the dried samples indicate that the chemical decomposition of Ni-, Co-, and Zn-based MOFs mainly occur in a similar temperature range of 300-350 °C, which is significantly lower than that of Mg-based MOFs (450-500 °C). In contrast, the analysis of the VT-PXRD patterns collected for the four MOFs leads to another trend regarding their framework collapse (Figures S9-S12). LIFM-13(Mg), LIFM-13(Co), and LIFM-13(Zn) retains their crystallinity up to 120 °C. LIFM-10(Ni) shows a much better stability of up to 400 °C. These results suggest that Mg-, Co-, and Zn-based MOFs lose their porosity after the solvents are removed. Nevertheless, LIFM-13(Ni) can maintain its crystallinity at a slightly higher temperature. This confirms that the Ni-based MOFs are more thermally stable when compared with the Mg-, Co-, and Zn-based analogues. On the basis of the Pearson's hard/soft acid/base (HSAB) principle, the in situ obtained ligand dimto offers both coordination sites of imidazole group as a soft Lewis base and oxygen group as a hard lewis base; thus we hypothesize that Ni2+, which is either too hard acid like Mg2+ or too soft acid like Co2+/Zn2+, acts as a borderline acid that fits well with the hybrid coordination environment, giving LIFM-13(Ni) the highest stability among its analogues. After all, this whole set of observations unveils that the thermal stability of a MOF may be different with regard to the chemical decomposition and the framework collapse.

elements.content: PXRD patterns of LIFM-13 series frameworks.
elements.clean_text: 2  PXRD patterns of LIFM-13 series frameworks.

elements.content: Successful activation of these MOFs upon removal of the guest solvents helps us to examine their gas adsorption properties. As shown in , the Ar­(87 K) adsorption of LIFM-13­(Zn) apparently performs a multistep isotherm which is often elucidated as a gate open/closed phenomenon, and related to structural flexibility. The first step of the isotherm exists at P/P 0 < 0.25, and the adsorption amount only reaches 26.7 mL/g with a BET surface area of 76.2 m2/g. Then, the isotherm dramatically rises to P/P 0 = 1 with an adsorption value of 244.3 mL/g and even remains rising upward, suggesting that the adsorption has not reached saturation. The desorption branch shows a large hysteresis, and the desorption curve began to turn downward at P/P 0 of 0.04. On the basis of the Ar­(87 K) isotherm of LIFM-13­(Zn), we consider that the framework undergoes a swelling process from closed apertures to open apertures. On the other hand, the Ar (87 K) adsorption measurements of LIFM-13­(Mg), LIFM-13­(Co), and LIFM-13­(Ni) perform Type-I isotherms that exhibit their microporous features. There is no obvious stepwise behavior observed in any of the isotherms. The BET surface areas are calculated as 424.7 m2/g for LIFM-13­(Mg), 357.3 m2/g for LIFM-13­(Co), and 1095.3 m2/g for LIFM-13­(Ni). The relatively large surface area of LIFM-13­(Ni) should be attributed to its fully removable solvent guest in apertures, and the framework can keep intact after activation, whereas LIFM-13­(Mg) and LIFM-13­(Co) most likely lost part of their crystallinity during guest removal. However, the pore size distributions calculated by the density functional theory (DFT) method based on Ar­(87 K) isotherms of LIFM-13­(Ni), LIFM-13­(Mg), and LIFM-13­(Co) are all around 1.0 nm (Figures S38–S40), proving the isoreticular frameworks of LIFM-13 series. (For the case of LIFM-13­(Zn), no fitting models are available for the rare shape of the isotherm, and thus the valid pore size distribution cannot be obtained.) We also performed N2(77 K) adsorption measurements on LIFM-13. Similar results are obtained as those of Ar (87 K). The N2 sorption measurements at 77 K show that LIFM-13­(Mg, Co, Zn) is characterized by lower gas uptakes than that of LIFM-13­(Ni), indicating that it lost the porosity during the activation procedure. Comparably, LIFM-13­(Ni) exhibits significant gas sorption capacities, showing the characteristic of a microporous solid, which is typical of type-I adsorption isotherms (Figure S13).
elements.clean_text: Successful activation of these MOFs upon removal of the guest solvents helps us to examine their gas adsorption properties. As shown in , the Ar(87 K) adsorption of LIFM-13(Zn) apparently performs a multistep isotherm which is often elucidated as a gate open/closed phenomenon, and related to structural flexibility. The first step of the isotherm exists at P/P 0 < 0.25, and the adsorption amount only reaches 26.7 mL/g with a BET surface area of 76.2 m2/g. Then, the isotherm dramatically rises to P/P 0 = 1 with an adsorption value of 244.3 mL/g and even remains rising upward, suggesting that the adsorption has not reached saturation. The desorption branch shows a large hysteresis, and the desorption curve began to turn downward at P/P 0 of 0.04. On the basis of the Ar(87 K) isotherm of LIFM-13(Zn), we consider that the framework undergoes a swelling process from closed apertures to open apertures. On the other hand, the Ar (87 K) adsorption measurements of LIFM-13(Mg), LIFM-13(Co), and LIFM-13(Ni) perform Type-I isotherms that exhibit their microporous features. There is no obvious stepwise behavior observed in any of the isotherms. The BET surface areas are calculated as 424.7 m2/g for LIFM-13(Mg), 357.3 m2/g for LIFM-13(Co), and 1095.3 m2/g for LIFM-13(Ni). The relatively large surface area of LIFM-13(Ni) should be attributed to its fully removable solvent guest in apertures, and the framework can keep intact after activation, whereas LIFM-13(Mg) and LIFM-13(Co) most likely lost part of their crystallinity during guest removal. However, the pore size distributions calculated by the density functional theory (DFT) method based on Ar(87 K) isotherms of LIFM-13(Ni), LIFM-13(Mg), and LIFM-13(Co) are all around 1.0 nm (Figures S38-S40), proving the isoreticular frameworks of LIFM-13 series. (For the case of LIFM-13(Zn), no fitting models are available for the rare shape of the isotherm, and thus the valid pore size distribution cannot be obtained.) We also performed N2(77 K) adsorption measurements on LIFM-13. Similar results are obtained as those of Ar (87 K). The N2 sorption measurements at 77 K show that LIFM-13(Mg, Co, Zn) is characterized by lower gas uptakes than that of LIFM-13(Ni), indicating that it lost the porosity during the activation procedure. Comparably, LIFM-13(Ni) exhibits significant gas sorption capacities, showing the characteristic of a microporous solid, which is typical of type-I adsorption isotherms (Figure S13).

elements.content: Ar (87 K) adsorption (filled symbols) and desorption (empty symbols) isotherms of (a) LIFM-13 (Zn, Mg, Co, Ni) and (b) on a semilogarithmic scale.
elements.clean_text: 3  Ar (87 K) adsorption (filled symbols) and desorption (empty symbols) isotherms of (a) LIFM-13 (Zn, Mg, Co, Ni) and (b) on a semilogarithmic scale.

elements.content: To investigate the gas separation properties of LIFM-13, CO2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, C3H6/CH4, C2H6/CH4, and C3H8/CH4 selectivity at 298 K was obtained from the adsorption isotherms of each gas (Figures S14–S25). The adsorption amounts are summarized in Table S3, and the selectivity is summarized in , which is calculated by Henry’s law method (Tables S4–S11). In the case of CO2/CH4 selectivity, LIFM-13­(Zn) exhibits the highest value of 9.55, while LIFM-13­(Ni) provides the smallest at 2.97. Hydrocarbons selectivity of flexible structures (LIFM-13­(Zn), LIFM-13­(Mg), LIFM-13­(Co)) also showed better performance than the rigid LIFM-13­(Ni). To confirm the results, we also performed gas selectivity calculation based on the ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) method for LIFM-13­(Zn) and LIFM-13­(Ni). The zero-coverage values were approximately the same with the values based on Henry’s law method (Figures S26–S29), and the values of selectivity are summarized in Table S12. We attribute the high selectivities among LIFM-13 to the multi N-heterocycles ligand that endows these MOFs higher affinity for CO2, C2H6, C2H4, C3H8, and C3H6 over CH4.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the gas separation properties of LIFM-13, CO2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, C3H6/CH4, C2H6/CH4, and C3H8/CH4 selectivity at 298 K was obtained from the adsorption isotherms of each gas (Figures S14-S25). The adsorption amounts are summarized in Table S3, and the selectivity is summarized in , which is calculated by Henry's law method (Tables S4-S11). In the case of CO2/CH4 selectivity, LIFM-13(Zn) exhibits the highest value of 9.55, while LIFM-13(Ni) provides the smallest at 2.97. Hydrocarbons selectivity of flexible structures (LIFM-13(Zn), LIFM-13(Mg), LIFM-13(Co)) also showed better performance than the rigid LIFM-13(Ni). To confirm the results, we also performed gas selectivity calculation based on the ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) method for LIFM-13(Zn) and LIFM-13(Ni). The zero-coverage values were approximately the same with the values based on Henry's law method (Figures S26-S29), and the values of selectivity are summarized in Table S12. We attribute the high selectivities among LIFM-13 to the multi N-heterocycles ligand that endows these MOFs higher affinity for CO2, C2H6, C2H4, C3H8, and C3H6 over CH4.

On the other hand, the adsorption amounts at 760 Torr for CO2 at 298, 288, and 273 K; for H2 at 77 K; for CH4 at 298 K; for C2H4 at 298 K; for C3H6 at 298 K; for C2H6 at 298 K; and for C3H8 at 298 K of LIFM-13­(Ni) all exhibit the highest values among their analogues, which is attributable to the robust framework that maximizes the porous volume to hold as many guests as it can. On the contrary, LIFM-13­(Mg), LIFM-13­(Co), and LIFM-13­(Zn) partially lost their crystallinity after activation, thus limiting their gas adsorption abilities. The coverage-dependent adsorption isosteric heat is calculated based on the virial method for CO2 and H2 (Figures S30–S37), which is summarized in Table S13. The values are moderate among the known MOFs.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, the adsorption amounts at 760 Torr for CO2 at 298, 288, and 273 K; for H2 at 77 K; for CH4 at 298 K; for C2H4 at 298 K; for C3H6 at 298 K; for C2H6 at 298 K; and for C3H8 at 298 K of LIFM-13(Ni) all exhibit the highest values among their analogues, which is attributable to the robust framework that maximizes the porous volume to hold as many guests as it can. On the contrary, LIFM-13(Mg), LIFM-13(Co), and LIFM-13(Zn) partially lost their crystallinity after activation, thus limiting their gas adsorption abilities. The coverage-dependent adsorption isosteric heat is calculated based on the virial method for CO2 and H2 (Figures S30-S37), which is summarized in Table S13. The values are moderate among the known MOFs.

elements.content: In summary, four isoreticular MOFs of ant topology containing quadrate pores have been constructed from multi-nitrogen heterocycle ligand and metal ions of Mg2+/Co2+/Ni2+/Zn2+. The impact of the metals on the stability and flexibility of these isoreticular MOFs has been evaluated. This study revealed that an appropriate selection of metal centers can help to optimize thermal stability and framework flexibility of MOFs with promising adsorption/separation properties for a wide range of gases (N2, CO2, CH4, and H2, light hydrocarbons (C1–C3)). In general, the Ni-based MOFs are more robust than those of Mg-based, Co-based, and Zn-based MOFs. These results suggest that fitting multi-nitrogen heterocycle into MOFs may provide a promising strategy for generating high selectivity, especially for that of natural gas purification.
elements.clean_text: In summary, four isoreticular MOFs of  ant  topology containing quadrate pores have been constructed from multi-nitrogen heterocycle ligand and metal ions of Mg2+/Co2+/Ni2+/Zn2+. The impact of the metals on the stability and flexibility of these isoreticular MOFs has been evaluated. This study revealed that an appropriate selection of metal centers can help to optimize thermal stability and framework flexibility of MOFs with promising adsorption/separation properties for a wide range of gases (N2, CO2, CH4, and H2, light hydrocarbons (C1-C3)). In general, the Ni-based MOFs are more robust than those of Mg-based, Co-based, and Zn-based MOFs. These results suggest that fitting multi-nitrogen heterocycle into MOFs may provide a promising strategy for generating high selectivity, especially for that of natural gas purification.

cln_elements.content: Successful activation of these MOFs upon removal of the guest solvents helps us to examine their gas adsorption properties. As shown in , the Ar­(87 K) adsorption of LIFM-13­(Zn) apparently performs a multistep isotherm which is often elucidated as a gate open/closed phenomenon, and related to structural flexibility. The first step of the isotherm exists at P/P 0 < 0.25, and the adsorption amount only reaches 26.7 mL/g with a BET surface area of 76.2 m2/g. Then, the isotherm dramatically rises to P/P 0 = 1 with an adsorption value of 244.3 mL/g and even remains rising upward, suggesting that the adsorption has not reached saturation. The desorption branch shows a large hysteresis, and the desorption curve began to turn downward at P/P 0 of 0.04. On the basis of the Ar­(87 K) isotherm of LIFM-13­(Zn), we consider that the framework undergoes a swelling process from closed apertures to open apertures. On the other hand, the Ar (87 K) adsorption measurements of LIFM-13­(Mg), LIFM-13­(Co), and LIFM-13­(Ni) perform Type-I isotherms that exhibit their microporous features. There is no obvious stepwise behavior observed in any of the isotherms. The BET surface areas are calculated as 424.7 m2/g for LIFM-13­(Mg), 357.3 m2/g for LIFM-13­(Co), and 1095.3 m2/g for LIFM-13­(Ni). The relatively large surface area of LIFM-13­(Ni) should be attributed to its fully removable solvent guest in apertures, and the framework can keep intact after activation, whereas LIFM-13­(Mg) and LIFM-13­(Co) most likely lost part of their crystallinity during guest removal. However, the pore size distributions calculated by the density functional theory (DFT) method based on Ar­(87 K) isotherms of LIFM-13­(Ni), LIFM-13­(Mg), and LIFM-13­(Co) are all around 1.0 nm (Figures S38–S40), proving the isoreticular frameworks of LIFM-13 series. (For the case of LIFM-13­(Zn), no fitting models are available for the rare shape of the isotherm, and thus the valid pore size distribution cannot be obtained.) We also performed N2(77 K) adsorption measurements on LIFM-13. Similar results are obtained as those of Ar (87 K). The N2 sorption measurements at 77 K show that LIFM-13­(Mg, Co, Zn) is characterized by lower gas uptakes than that of LIFM-13­(Ni), indicating that it lost the porosity during the activation procedure. Comparably, LIFM-13­(Ni) exhibits significant gas sorption capacities, showing the characteristic of a microporous solid, which is typical of type-I adsorption isotherms (Figure S13).
cln_elements.clean_text: Successful activation of these MOFs upon removal of the guest solvents helps us to examine their gas adsorption properties. As shown in , the Ar(87 K) adsorption of LIFM-13(Zn) apparently performs a multistep isotherm which is often elucidated as a gate open/closed phenomenon, and related to structural flexibility. The first step of the isotherm exists at P/P 0 < 0.25, and the adsorption amount only reaches 26.7 mL/g with a BET surface area of 76.2 m2/g. Then, the isotherm dramatically rises to P/P 0 = 1 with an adsorption value of 244.3 mL/g and even remains rising upward, suggesting that the adsorption has not reached saturation. The desorption branch shows a large hysteresis, and the desorption curve began to turn downward at P/P 0 of 0.04. On the basis of the Ar(87 K) isotherm of LIFM-13(Zn), we consider that the framework undergoes a swelling process from closed apertures to open apertures. On the other hand, the Ar (87 K) adsorption measurements of LIFM-13(Mg), LIFM-13(Co), and LIFM-13(Ni) perform Type-I isotherms that exhibit their microporous features. There is no obvious stepwise behavior observed in any of the isotherms. The BET surface areas are calculated as 424.7 m2/g for LIFM-13(Mg), 357.3 m2/g for LIFM-13(Co), and 1095.3 m2/g for LIFM-13(Ni). The relatively large surface area of LIFM-13(Ni) should be attributed to its fully removable solvent guest in apertures, and the framework can keep intact after activation, whereas LIFM-13(Mg) and LIFM-13(Co) most likely lost part of their crystallinity during guest removal. However, the pore size distributions calculated by the density functional theory (DFT) method based on Ar(87 K) isotherms of LIFM-13(Ni), LIFM-13(Mg), and LIFM-13(Co) are all around 1.0 nm (Figures S38-S40), proving the isoreticular frameworks of LIFM-13 series. (For the case of LIFM-13(Zn), no fitting models are available for the rare shape of the isotherm, and thus the valid pore size distribution cannot be obtained.) We also performed N2(77 K) adsorption measurements on LIFM-13. Similar results are obtained as those of Ar (87 K). The N2 sorption measurements at 77 K show that LIFM-13(Mg, Co, Zn) is characterized by lower gas uptakes than that of LIFM-13(Ni), indicating that it lost the porosity during the activation procedure. Comparably, LIFM-13(Ni) exhibits significant gas sorption capacities, showing the characteristic of a microporous solid, which is typical of type-I adsorption isotherms (Figure S13).

metadata.title:
Metal Effects on
the Framework Stability and Adsorption
Property of a Series of Isoreticular Metal–Organic Frameworks
Based on an in-Situ Generated T‑Shaped Ligand
